page.title: 05Lace Maker, Houghton
page.content: The Houghton lace maker and has been teaching for 13 years. She first went to learn the craft when she was 12. She produces trinket boxes, brooches, hankies and various gifts. The lace is made using bobbins. Each thread is held by a seperate bobbin. A pattern is used called a pricking which has tiny prick holes marked on it. The design is created by weaving the bobbins through the pins and for complicated patterns as many as 200 bobbins are used. The different kinds of bobbins are glass, wood, bone and plastic. Hanging bobbins bear the names of people who were hanged in the 1800s. She prefers to use natural threads e.g. linen and silk, since synthetic threads are not suitable for lace making. It takes about an hour to make a square inch of fine lace. She usually works for two hours a day.
